review.title: Identification and classification of TCM syndrome types among patients with vascular mild cognitive impairment using latent tree analysis
review.abstract: Objective: To treat patients with vascular mild cognitive impairment (VMCI) using TCM, it is necessary to classify the patients into TCM syndrome types and to apply different treatments to different types. We investigate how to properly carry out the classification using a novel data-driven method known as latent tree analysis.

metadata.title: Identification and classification of TCM syndrome types among patients with vascular mild cognitive impairment using latent tree analysis

sections.text: Aim: In order to treat patients with vascular mild cognitive impairment (VMCI) with TCM, it is necessary to classify patients in TCM syndrome types and apply different treatments to different types. We are investigating how classification can be properly performed using a novel data-driven method, called latent tree analysis. Methods: A cross-sectional study of VMCI was conducted in several regions of northern China between 2008 and 2011, resulting in a data set comprising 803 patients and 93 symptoms. Latent tree analysis was performed on the basis of the data to identify symptom patterns, and patients were divided in various ways based on the patterns in clusters. Patient clusters were matched with symptom types, and population statistics from the clusters are used to quantify the syndrome types and classification rules.Results: Eight syndrome types are identified: Deficiency Deficiency Ciciency, Stalagnation of Blood, Classification of Disease Stagi, Phagency of Stagency.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: It is one of the most important diseases that have a significant impact on the health and quality of life of the elderly. In 2005, the global prevalence of dementia was estimated at 32.85 million, and the number of dementia cases is expected to double every 20 years, to 65.7 million in 2035 and 131.4 million in 2055. Dementia can be classified as a degenerative, vascular or other type of dementia based on itsetiology. Up to 34% of dementia cases show significant vascular pathology [2-7]. Recently, the construct of "vascular cognitive impairment" has been introduced to cover the full spectrum of cognitive disorders ranging from mild cognitive impairment to fully developed dementia caused or associated with vascular factors [8].

sections.heading: 3. Method
sections.text: The result is a latent tree model with several latent variables. Some of the latent variables have probable symptoms. 2. Patterns, while other patterns are revealed. 4. Patterns. The aim of the method is to uncover symptom patterns hidden in the data and to use these patterns to identify patient clusters corresponding to different TCM syndrome types. Statistical characteristics of the patient clusters are then used as quantitative characteristics of the syndrome types, and syndrome classification rules are established thereby. Analysis was carried out using lantern software [22]. There were five steps: 1. Pattern recognition: In the first step, latent tree analysis was performed to reveal obvious symptom types hidden in the VMCI data. The lantern includes two algorithms for this purpose. (Extension adjustment simplification until termination) algorithm [23] was used. The result is a tree model with multiple latents.

sections.heading: 4.4 Syndrome Quantification
sections.text: In the previous section, eight syndrome types were identified, which were also supported by data. A list of symptom groups was compiled for each syndrome type. In the next step, we use these symptom groups to identify groups of patients that correspond to the syndrome types and use the population statistics of the patient groups to quantify the syndrome types, using the Joint Clustering function of Lantern.

sections.text: As a result, the number of patients choosing treatment has multiplied in recent years.

sections.heading: 4.4.4 A Technical Note
sections.text: We conclude this section with a subtle technical note on clustering and explain the problem using the common cluster model for Qi deficiency (Figure 2). In the global model (Figure 3 in [19]), two symptom groups Y26 (chest compression, palpitation) and Y27 (shortness of breath) are used in the model. In the common cluster model, the symptom variable shortness under Y27 is grouped with sighing and three other symptom variables. In the common cluster model, sighing and the other variables are excluded. Short breathing may therefore need to be regrouped with other symptom variables from other countries in order to properly model the dependence between the variables. In Lantern, there is a search procedure that decides whether a regrouping is necessary and how it should be performed. In the common cluster model for Qi deficiency, short breathing is automatically merged with Y26 (chest compression, palpitation) and a new W is generated.

sections.heading: 5 Discussions
sections.text: TCM syndromes are latent variables that cannot be "measured" directly; they can only be "measured" indirectly by symptoms. Based on symptoms discovered in data and domain knowledge, we have identified eight groups of symptoms that can be "measured" by eight syndrome types each in patients with VMCI. Patients are divided into clusters based on each symptom group, with one of the patient clusters matching the syndrome type. Patient cluster population statistics are used to quantify the syndrome type (Section 4.4) and establish a classification rule (Section 4.5).

sections.heading: 5.1 Quality of Results
sections.text: In TCM theory, however, there is a qualitative understanding of which symptoms are the most important factors to take into account when determining whether a patient belongs to a syndrome type. They are called key factors of syndrome differentiation or bian zheng yao dian in Chinese. Our results fit well with these key factors, and they also satisfactorily reflect the characteristics of the studied VMCI population.

sections.heading: 5.1.1 Results on Blood Deficiency
sections.text: According to the TCM theory, the key factors for determining blood deficiency are pale lips, pale or pale complexion, dizziness, palpitations, insomnia and a thin pulse. All of these symptoms can be found in our classification rule for blood deficiency (Section 4.5). The symptoms with the highest scores are blurred vision and dry eyes, reflecting the characteristics of the population studied, which consists of patients with VMCI and older than 50 years. According to the TCM theory, seniors usually suffer from kidney deficiency, which can lead to liver deficiency (liver and kidney come from the same source), and therefore poor vision (the opening of the liver is located on the eye). According to our quantification results for the syndrome (Section 4.4), blurred vision and dry eyes with the highest probabilities (0.82 and 0.69) occur in the blood deficiency class. Palpitations and insomnia also occur with a high probability (0.56 and 0.60).

sections.heading: 5.1.2 Results on Blood Stasis
sections.text: According to the TCM theory, the key factors for determining blood stasis are locally intangible stabbing pain and color changes on the face, lips and tongue. In our blood stasis classification rule, the symptoms with the highest values are consistent purple or dark lips, dark complexion, blackish lower eyelid. The rule also includes tongue with ecchymosis and dark tongue. However, our rule does not correspond well to the TCM theory regarding local non-groping pain. In the VMCI dataset, there are only symptoms of stabbing pain, i.e. stabbing headache. stabbing pain in other parts of the body was not included in the survey due to its absence in the TCM literature on chi dai dai or dai bing. Stabbing headache occurred with very low frequency (< 3%) and it is negative and poorly correlated with other blood stasis symptoms.

sections.heading: 5.1.3 Results on Qi Deficiency
sections.text: According to the theory of TCM, the key factors for determining Qi deficiency are lack of strength, shortness of breath and inertia of the limbs and the body. In our classification rule for Qi deficiency, these are among the symptoms with the highest values. In addition, the four symptoms of waist or knee pain, urinary incontinence, chest and heart palpitations also have high values, reflecting the characteristics of the population studied. Patients in the population are elderly and therefore likely to suffer from kidney deficiency, which manifests itself in painful waist or knees and urinary incontinence. Patients in the population all suffer from vascular MCI (mild cognitive impairment).The vascular factors can affect the heart and lead to chest and heart palpitations.According to our quantification results, the symptoms of chest pressure, palpitations and painful waist or knees are most likely to occur in the Qi deficiency class. Those who are suffering from Qi deficiency mainly in the heart and kidney deficiency population.

sections.heading: 5.1.4 Results on Qi Stagnation
sections.text: According to the TCM theory, the key factors for determining qi stagnation are stomach swelling and fullness, bloating pain and sighing. In our classification rule for blood qi stagnation, the symptoms with the highest values correspond to breast swelling, sighing, hypochondrium flatulence or pain and abdominal bloating.

sections.heading: 5.1.5 Results on Fire-Heat
sections.text: According to the theory of TCM, the most common manifestations of fire-heat are flushedface, thirst, dry stools or constipation, red tongue, yellow tongue skin and fast pulse. In our fire-heat classification rule, dry stools or constipation and thirst for cold drinks have high values. The other top score symptoms are aphtha in the mouth or on the tongue, fatty halitosis, acid swallowing or epigastric mood, insomnia, throbbing headache and restlessness or short-term temper. In TCM, these symptoms are considered manifestations of excessive heat. However, the symptoms of flushface, red tongue, yellow tongue and fast pulses are not present in our classification rule. They correlate weakly with the symptoms mentioned above in the data set.

sections.heading: 5.1.6 Results on Phlegm-Dampness
sections.text: According to the theory of TCM, the key factors for determining mucous membrane moisture are the presence of visible and invisible mucus, oily tongue membrane and slippery pulse. Accordingly, oily tongue membrane and slippery pulse have high values in our mucous membrane moisture classification rule. Dizziness and dizziness (invisible mucus) are also present. The important role of dizziness and dizziness in general is consistent with TCM's claim that mucus blockage of brain collateral is an important pathogenic factor.

sections.heading: 5.1.7 Results on Yin Deficiency
sections.text: According to the theory of TCM, the manifestations of yin deficiency fall mainly into two categories: those caused by the lack of intestines and organs due to the lack of yin fluid, and those caused by the relative excess of yang due to the failure of yin to rein in yang. In our classification rule for yin deficiency, the symptoms of yin deficiency are painful waist or knee, blurred vision, dry eyes and tinnitus representative symptoms of the first category, while insomnia, dreaminess, palpitations, expectation are representative symptoms of the second category. According to the theory of TCM, the key features of yin deficiency in internal heat are red and dry tongue, little tongue fur and thin and fast pulse. In our rule to distinguish between yin deficiency II (with internal heat) and yin deficiency I, the main features of yin deficiency in internal heat are dry tongue and red tongue, and fast and thin powder and powder.

sections.heading: 5.1.8 Results on Yang Deficiency
sections.text: Our classification rule for yang deficiency syndrome fits well with the TCM theory in the sense that all of the symptoms usually contained are closely related to yang deficiency according to the TCM theory. In fact, the symptoms are fear of cold or cold limbs, thirst for hot drink, undigested food in the stool and diarrhea before dawn, the cold symptoms of yang deficiency. Symptoms of painful waist or knees, blackened lower eyelids, frequent night urination and a weak complexion indicate a kidney deficiency. In addition, palpitations and breast suppression lead to rapid heart rate. Weak spleen yang leads to malnutrition of muscles and meridians, which leads to sluggishness of the limbs and body. Note that the three symptoms lead to painful waist or knee, blackened lower eyelid thirst and dizziness in both Yang deficiency and general calf disturbance.

sections.heading: 5.2 Uses of Results
sections.text: Our classification rules are based on scores and are therefore convenient to use. In fact, they can be applied in three scenarios. Firstly, a major weakness of TCM is the lack of gold standards for syndrome medication differentiation. In clinical practice, different physicians can draw different conclusions about the syndrome type of the same patient. This affects the effectiveness of treatments and undermines patient confidence. Secondly, randomized controlled trials (RCTs) can be widely used to determine the effectiveness of TCM treatments. To perform RCT for treatment with a TCM syndrome type, these types must be used as the basis for developing syndrome differentiation standards for VMCI. Secondly, use randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to determine the effectiveness of TCM treatments.

sections.heading: 5.3 Strengths and Limitations
sections.text: In this paper, we address the problem of classifying VMCI patients into TCM syndrome types. Results are quantitative in nature. Eight syndrome types are identified, and prevalence and score-based classification rules are obtained for each of the syndrome types. Results are obtained using the latent tree analysis method. Consequently, they enjoy stronger evidence support than solutions that could be obtained with the alternative approaches, namely expert standardization and monitored quantification approaches [19]. Expert standardization, on the other hand, establishes solutions for the syndrome classification by expert panels. In supervised quantification, experts are asked to identify the syndrome types of individual patients. In both cases, the results strongly depend on who the experts are. However, the latent tree analysis method is based only on symptom data. Results are relatively more objective. One limitation of our work is that the data collected for all purposes of the study in North China would be of interest to other parts of the country, as it is mainly used in other parts of the country.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: By analyzing symptom data collected from 803 VMCI patients 50 years of age or older using latent tree models, we have concluded that there are eight types of TCM syndromes in the population: anaemia, hemostasis, phlegm humidity, fire heat, qi deficiency, qi stagnation, yang deficiency and yin deficiency. In addition, two subtypes of yin deficiency have been identified, namely yin deficiency with and without internal heat. The prevalence and probability of symptoms occurring for the syndrome types and subtypes have been determined, and appropriate classification rules have been established. Results are well in line with TCM theory and enjoy the strongest evidence currently possible.Cometing Interests' The authors explain that they have no competing interests, financial or non-occurring probabilities for the syndrome types and subtypes.

Recently, the construct of “vascular cognitive impairment” (VCI) has been introduced to capture the entire spectrum of cognitive disorders, ranging from mild cognitive impairment to fully developed dementia, that are caused by or associated with vascular factors [8].

VCI has three subtypes: Vascular dementia (VaD), Alzheimer's disease (AD) with a vascular component (mixed dementia), and the pre-dementia stage that is referred to as vascular mild cognitive impairment (VMCI or VaMCI) [9].
Some studies have shown that 46% of patients with VMCI developed dementia after five years [12].
